description.plain:
Manic Street Preachers were formed in 1986 in Blackwood, Wales. Composed of James Dean Bradfield (lead vocals, lead guitar), Nicky Wire (backing vocals, bass guitar), Richey Edwards (rhythm guitar) and Sean Moore (drums), they released three albums between 1992 and 1994. The band quickly became known for their anger, punk-influenced sound, political lyrics, and live performances. Songwriting duties were shared across the band: Edwards and Wire wrote most of the lyrics, while Bradfield and Moore composed the music.

On 1 February 1995, Richey Edwards disappeared after checking out of a hotel in London. He was to fly to the US to promote the band’s new album, The Holy Bible. Despite an investigation and several clues and possible leads, Edwards' fate is unknown. The band continued to perform and record Edwards' songs, and for many years paid royalties into an account in his name.

In the aftermath of Edwards' disappearance, Wire became the band’s sole lyricist. Among the band’s hit songs from this period (the late 1990s) were “The Masses Against the Classes”, “Your Love Alone Is Not Enough”, and" If You Tolerate This Your Children Will Be Next“. Their albums Everything Must Go and This Is My Truth Tell Me Yours also rated high in the charts.

In 2008, nearly 14 years after his disappearance, Richey Edwards was declared to be presumed dead under English law. The band turned a folder of Richey’s writings into songs and released Journal For Plague Lovers, which was the Manics' most critically-acclaimed album since The Holy Bible.

The band continues to write and record new music; their most recent album, The Ultra Vivid Lament, was released in 2021.

songs.full_title: Motorcycle Emptiness by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Motorcycle Emptiness

description.plain:
While Generation Terrorists has its critics, no sage soul has a bad word to say about “Motorcycle Emptiness” – and with good reason, because it remains one of the Manics’ glittering high-points.

To this day, it shines as an undimmed soul-trodden elegy, buoyed by some of James Dean Bradfield’s finest fretwork, and topped off with Richey Edwards and Nicky Wire’s typically brilliant poetic flourishes.

songs.title_with_featured: If You Tolerate This Your Children Will Be Next

description.plain: This is about the Spanish Civil War, and the idealism of people from around the world who volunteered to be part of the International Brigade fighting Franco’s fascist army. The track became the band’s first UK #1 single, making it their joint highest-charting single alongside “The Masses Against the Classes”.

songs.full_title: Yes by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Yes

description.plain:
The first track from The Holy Bible, this was written by Richey Edwards from the perspective of a prostitute. It samples the 1993 documentary Hookers, Hustlers, Pimps and their Johns, by Beeban Kidron, about the prostitution trade



Whilst the sex trade provides the main thrust of the song on the surface, there is a strong allegory between the experiences of the prostitute and the songwriter in the undercurrent. The song uses images of self-abuse and the feelings of being sold to the highest bidder all of which were pertinent to the life of Edwards.

Being the opening track on the album ‘The Holy Bible’ Yes  sets the tone for what is to become a voyage into the depths of the human psyche.

songs.full_title: Ifwhiteamericatoldthetruthforonedayit'sworldwouldfallapart by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Ifwhiteamericatoldthetruthforonedayit’sworldwouldfallapart

description.plain:
It’s not a completely anti-American song. It compares British imperialism to American consumerism. It’s just trying to explain the confusion I think most people feel about how the most empty culture in the world can dominate in such a total sense.

So said Nicky Wire in a 1994 Melody Maker interview. A strange defence, perhaps, of a song which seems to have nothing positive to say about America. According to “Ifwhiteamerica…”, American culture is vacuous and its disastrous foreign interventions are only matched by its hapless domestic policy. Later, Wire would clarify:

I know people are going to think ‘Yank-bashing’ straightaway, but I don’t want it to be construed as that. I’m not part of this thing that thinks British music is the best and we should all stay in Britain and wave the Union Jack and then things will be great. It’s just that people do bow down to American culture. Sometimes I think I’ve got to make myself like basketball and stuff like that, but I just can’t.

The bulk of the song’s lyrics were written by Wire, but Richey Edwards contributed a few lines. Most notably, the “Zapruder” line bamboozled Wire at first. As usual, the song’s music was arranged by James Dean Bradfield and Sean Moore.

Note: The actual title of the song is written as “Ifwhiteamericatoldthetruthforonedayit'sworldwouldfallapart”, but it has been spaced out to avoid formatting issues.

songs.full_title: A Design for Life by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: A Design for Life

description.plain:
“A Design For Life” was written by Nicky Wire, with music by James Dean Bradfield and Sean Moore, and explores working class identity in Britain.

It was their first single following the disappearance of Richey Edwards, peaking at #2 in the UK. It was also track #2 on Everything Must Go, and has featured on all the band’s compilation albums – unsurprisingly, as it has become their most well-known song.

Its video included scenes of fox hunting and Royal Ascot to represent what the band saw as class privilege.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TfEoVxy7VDQ

songs.full_title: Archives of Pain by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Archives of Pain

description.plain:
This controversial song can be read in a variety of ways. The lyrics are a pro-death penalty look at media glorification of serial killers, but it is not clear whether the words actually advocate capital punishment, if they are meant to be an ironic look at a perspective which advocates it, or if they are purposely inconclusive on the matter.

The title was based on Foucault. Contrary to Nicky Wire’s statement (below), there is no chapter in any book by Foucault called “Archives of Pain”. He only uses the expression once, in a preface. It was, however, the name of a chapter in a biography about him.

songs.full_title: P.C.P. by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: P.C.P.

description.plain:
The last track on The Holy Bible. Here’s what Richey Edwards has to say about the song:

Links PC PCP New Moral Certainty. Language aimed at the working class. Condemns the very people it aims to save. Self-censorship wrong. “Liviticus” used by homophobes to justify their hatred. To take one sentence from the bible to justify views very PC. Also PCP the Revolutionary Portuguese Communist.

Bassist Nicky Wire interprets the song as a cathartic critique of political correctness and repression of free speech.

songs.full_title: The Intense Humming of Evil by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: The Intense Humming of Evil

description.plain: The penultimate track on The Holy Bible, this song was inspired by the Manics' visits to Dachau, Belsen and the Peace Museum in Hiroshima. It is a sister song of “Mausoleum”. It is perhaps the most unnerving track on the album, with James Dean Bradfield’s fractured guitar tone and Sean Moore’s chugging drum beat, whether intentionally or not, mirroring the sound of the train’s that would carry those prosecuted in the Holocaust to the death camps.

It is perhaps the most unnerving track on the album, with James Dean Bradfield’s fractured guitar tone and Sean Moore’s chugging drum beat, whether intentionally or not, mirroring the sound of the train’s that would carry those prosecuted in the Holocaust to the death camps.

songs.lyrics:
[Sampled Intro]
"The court has come. The court of the Nations. And into the courtroom will come the martyrs of Majdanek, and Oswiecim. From the ditch of Kerch, the dead will rise. They will arise from the graves, they will arise from flames bringing with them the acrid smoke and the deathly odour of scorched and martyred Europe. And the children, they too will come, stern and merciless. The butchers had no pity on them; now the victims will judge the butchers. Today the tear of the child is the judge. The grief of the mother is the prosecutor."

[Verse 1]
You were what you were
Clean cut, and unbecoming
Recreation for the masses
You always mistook fists for flowers

[Bridge]
Welcome welcome soldier smiling
Funeral march for agony's last edge

[Chorus]

Maybe misery - maybe nothing at all
Lives that wouldn't have changed a thing
Never counted - never mattered - never be

[Verse 2]
Arbeit macht frei
Transports of invalids
Hartheim Castle breathes us in
In block 5 we worship malaria
Lagerstrasse, poplar trees
Beauty lost, dignity gone
Rascher surveys us butcher bacteria
[Bridge]
Welcome welcome soldier smiling
Funeral march for agony's last edge

[Chorus]
6 Million screaming souls
Maybe misery - maybe nothing at all
Lives that wouldn't have changed a thing
Never counted - never mattered - never be

[Outro]
Drink it away, every tear is false
Churchill no different
Wished the workers bled to a machine1EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Kevin Carter by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Kevin Carter

description.plain:
This song, penned by Richey Edwards before his disappearance, is written about the life and death of Pulitzer Prize-winning photojournalist Kevin Carter. Carter committed suicide in 1994, three months after winning a Pulitzer Prize for an image he took the previous year of a starving child crawling to a food station that was some distance away.



The song seems to highlight the disconnect between the fame Carter gained and the photographs of unspeakable atrocities he took, and the way this cognitive dissonance eventually drove Carter to take his own life.

songs.full_title: Little Baby Nothing by Manic Street Preachers (Ft. Traci Lords)
songs.title: Little Baby Nothing

description.plain:
Manic’s 1992 feminist anthem, released as the last single to Generation Terrorists was a minor success at the time but went on to become one of the band’s classics.



James Bradfield described this song as an attempt to write “something the E-Street Band might play”. It was also written with the idea of having a female voice singing with him.

The band tried having Kylie Minogue recording the vocals, but she was unable to do it. Five years later, the Manics would co-write a couple of songs in Minogue’s Impossible Princess album.

The duet ended up being with former porn actress Traci Lords, which actually fits well with the song’s themes of objectification and exploitation of women. She said she

listened to the tape and really identified with the character in the song… this young girl who’s been exploited and abused by men all her life.
https://youtu.be/AKNkhQKl-pc

Traci Lords would a couple of years later start a career as a singer.

songs.full_title: Everything Must Go by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Everything Must Go

description.plain:
The second single and title track from Everything Must Go is one of the band’s most well-known and commercially successful singles, making it to #5 in the UK Singles Chart, making it the band’s second of five consecutive top 10 singles.

The lyrics deal with the band’s change of direction after the disappearance of Richey James Edwards in 1995, pleading towards their fans to accept their new, commercial continuation of the band despite losing one of their key songwriters. Like the previous single, “A Design for Life”, the track makes extensive use of cinematic and epic strings. The decision was also made not to apply any compression to the drums, giving them a free and messy sound.

A remix of this song, made by The Chemical Brothers, features in the soundtrack of the 1998 PlayStation video game Gran Turismo.

songs.full_title: You Stole the Sun from My Heart by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: You Stole the Sun from My Heart
songs.title_with_featured: You Stole the Sun from My Heart

description.plain:
“You Stole the Sun from My Heart” is the third single from This is My Truth Tell Me Yours and makes a return to to the crunchy, rocky power chords that had been missing from the first two tracks on the album. The verses are built on a simple, picked guitar riff, accompanied by a gentle drum machine (apparently sampled from the sound of a pinball machine), but the chorus that follows is an anthemic crowd pleaser. The lyrics deal with Nicky Wire’s distaste for touring, although at a deeper level it explores the idea of losing one’s soul.

It was very commercially successful, peaking at #5 in the UK charts, but it is rarely played live anymore.

songs.title: Distant Colours

description.plain:
Manic Street Preachers' second single released on the 16th of February 2018 from their 13th studio album Resistance is Futile. Lyrics written by singer and guitarist James Dean Bradfield about his youth and growing up in Wales. Resistance is Futile captures “widescreen melancholia” and is “obsessively melodic, using art as a means of escaping.” It is set for release on the 13th of April 2018. Available for pre-order now: https://store.manicstreetpreachers.com/products/resistance-is-futile-cd

Watch the video for Distant Colours: https://youtu.be/7RZzxbZ6WWY

songs.full_title: The Everlasting by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: The Everlasting

description.plain:
“The Everlasting” is perhaps the most striking opening track from any of the Manic Street Preachers' albums. A departure from the aggressive guitar-driven rock of the band’s previous albums, “The Everlasting” is unlike anything the Manics had released previously. It is long, epic and elegiac, featuring a very prominent string section led by violinist Sally Herbert and a drum machine, this time sounding much more synthetic than those that appeared on Generation Terrorists.

Lyrically, the song deals with themes of ageing, refugees and racism. These are all themes that have appeared in Manics songs before, but they are presented in a much more doubtful and contemplative way.

songs.full_title: Stay Beautiful by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Stay Beautiful

description.plain:
“Stay Beautiful” was one of the first tracks worked on for Generation Terrorists as it was sent in its demo form to Steve Brown to convince him to work on the album after difficulties finding a producer to work with. It was to be the first single released from the album on 29th July 1991 before the album’s release in February 1992.

The track is well known for it’s call and response chorus in which the audience are encouraged to fill in the gap (the gap being the phrase ‘fuck off’) .

The expletive was actually meant to be part of the song and was in the demo version sent to Steve Brown but in a clever twist (and to make it more radio friendly) he replaced the expletive with the now iconic guitar sound in it’s place but if you listen carefully you can hear where the edit was made. This was revealed in the documentary Culture, Alienation, Boredom & Despair which can be found with certain 20th Anniversary editions of Generation Terrorists.

The track was a live staple early in the Manics' live shows performed under the name “Generation Terrorists”.

With this song, the band crashed the UK Top 40 for the first time.

songs.full_title: Australia by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Australia

description.plain:
This song is partly inspired by the mysterious disappearance of the band’s rhythm guitarist and chief songwriter Richey Edwards. Edwards disappeared in February 1995, on the day he and frontman James Dean Bradfield were due to fly to the United States for a promotional tour. In the years since Edwards hasn’t reemerged nor has his body been found.
Driven by rapid drums, heavy but melodic guitars, and pain-ridden lyrics about wanting to be far away from the media during their darkest moment, this song helped the Manics move past Edwards' disappearance and continue on with their career.

The first track off of Manic Street Preachers' ninth album; Journal For Plague Lovers. All of the lyrics to feature on the record are some of the last (or the very last) things that were written by ‘rhythm guitarist’/lyricist: Richey Edwards before his unfortunate disappearance in 1995.



This song in particular takes on the aftermath of Richey’s life after treatment in The Priory for his depression, alcoholism, self mutilation and anorexia, American culture and politics

songs.full_title: Tsunami by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Tsunami

description.plain:
“Tsunami” is a biography of June and Jennifer Gibbons, the so-called “Silent Twins” who refused to speak to anyone but each other in a self-invented language from an early age. They came to the attention of the general public after turning to petty crime to gain recognition for their literary talents and being sentenced to detention at Broadmoor Hospital, a high-security mental health hospital.

The girls formed a pact which stated that, if one were to die, the other must start talking again and live a full and happy life, and indeed eventually came to believe one of them would HAVE to die in order for the other to live. When Jennifer died in March 1993, June fulfilled her end of the bargain, stating “I’m free at last, liberated, and at last Jennifer has given up her life for me.”

The “Tsunami” of the song’s title is the feeling of relief that came rushing over June when she was finally free of the pact with her sister, and the song itself deals with the complexities of their relationship and how living so closely bound to another person fundamentally affects how you view yourself and the world.

songs.full_title: Orwellian by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Orwellian

description.plain:
“Orwellian” deals with “the battle to claim meaning” in the digital media age, with the looming sense of unease and confusion of the current political climate. Its title refers to writer George Orwell, comparing the corruption and truth-control of modern-day Britain with the totalitarian regimes of Orwell’s Animal Farm and Nineteen Eighty-Four. This isn’t the first time the Manics have touched upon issues of political correctness and censorship, having dealt with it explicitly on 1994’s “PCP”.

The song’s release coincided with the announcement of the band’s 14th studio album, The Ultra Vivid Lament, 24 hours after a mysterious album trailer appeared on their YouTube channel. Sonically, the track is a mid-tempo and piano-heavy rock song, which pays homage to pop legends ABBA, as well as new wave groups Talk Talk and The Associates.

songs.full_title: Ocean Spray by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Ocean Spray

description.plain:
Ocean Spray is the second track and third single off of Know Your Enemy.

The first of the band’s songs to feature lyrics written by Bradfield, it is inspired by the passing of his mother Sue. During 1999, the Manics delayed a US tour so that Bradfield could visit her when she was being treated for cancer. During the visits they would drink Ocean Spray cranberry juice together, hence the origin of the song.

songs.full_title: Elvis Impersonator: Blackpool Pier by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Elvis Impersonator: Blackpool Pier

description.plain:
The opening track from Everything Must Go describes an overweight Elvis impersonator on a pier in Blackpool as an example of how the American pop culture is ingrained in UK, even in decadent and cheap forms. It laments the way the Britain is slowly being Americanised and the way the British accept and even worship it. It is also one of the few tracks on the album co-written by former rhythm guitarist Richey James Edwards.

The beginning of the song consists of only acoustic guitars, some subtle plucked harp notes and James Dean Bradfield’s vocals, but this suddenly erupts into a classic Manics rocker.

songs.full_title: The Masses Against the Classes by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: The Masses Against the Classes

description.plain:
On the surface, this is a song about the Manics' beloved socialism, but lyricist Nicky Wire disagreed with this interpretation in a 2011 interview:

It’s actually not a particularly political song. It’s actually a song about us. “Hello it’s us again” – it’s like a rewrite of “You Love Us” really, just that idea that ten years on we might become one of the biggest bands in Britain but we’re basically still the same.

The cover art is the Cuban flag without its star. The single was available for purchase for less than 24 hours, yet still managed to top the UK singles chart, as the first UK number one on the turn of the millennium (2000) as well as the second and final chart-topping song by the Manics after “If You Tolerate This Your Children Will Be Next”.

songs.full_title: From Despair to Where by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: From Despair to Where

description.plain:
“From Despair to Where” was released as the lead single from Manic Street Preachers' sophomore album, Gold Against the Soul, reaching #25 in the UK singles chart. Richey James Edwards described its lyrical themes to Melody Maker in 1993:

In the Western world, living conditions really aren’t that bad. Most people have somewhere to live and enough to eat – and yet most people are unhappy. I don’t think many people ever come home at night thinking ‘What a great day that was!’ And that’s why totalitarianism will always be tempting – because a fascist leader can say ‘I’ll make all your decisions for you. You don’t need to have any responsibilities. I’ll take care of your life.’

The band’s first recorded output in eight months, the track hinted at the more textured sound that would dominate Gold Against the Soul, featuring a string section and an organ in addition the band’s usual guitar/bass/drums setup. James Dean Bradfield’s vocals on the opening verse are also much softer and more delicate than anything on their previous album, Generation Terrorists, though they become much more aggressive when the rest of the band comes in at “There’s nothing nice in my head”.

The music video, which was directed by Peter Scammel, cuts between scenes of the Manics performing the song and what appears to be two masked figures fighting each other in a red-lit room.

songs.full_title: Theme from M.A.S.H. (Suicide Is Painless) by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Theme from M.A.S.H. (Suicide Is Painless)

description.plain:
Originally recorded for the NME’s Ruby Trax charity compilation album of UK Number One singles to celebrate their 40 year anniversary, “Suicide is Painless” quickly became a stand out track in the Manics' catalogue reaching number 7 in the UK Singles Chart in September 1992.

The song itself is a cover of the theme song to both the television series and it’s predecessor feature length film, M*A*S*H and was written by Johnny Mandel and Michael Altman in 1970. The original (described by the film’s director Robert Altman himself as the wanting the “Stupidest song ever written” for the film and the track itself ended up being written by Robert Altman’s 14 year old son Michael who apparently wrote the lyrics in approximately 5 minutes) reached number one in the UK in 1980.

The single was released alongside a cover of “Everything I Do (I Do It For You)” by The Fatima Mansions with the proceeds going to The Spastics Society (now known as Scope). The track was later to be included as a bonus track on the 20th anniversary editions of Generation Terrorists and vastly became a fan favourite.

songs.title: Jackie Collins Existential Question Time

description.plain:
Although none of the tracks from Journal For Plague Lovers were released as singles, “Jackie Collins Existential Question Time” and “Peeled Apples” still received significant radio playing time.

Richey Edwards' lyrics about author Jackie Collins' absurd metaphysical chat show were arranged by James Dean Bradfield and Nicky Wire, who wrote the music for the chorus.

The track starts with a distorted guitar riff, foreshadowing the chorus, before settling on a cleaner one undercut with a growling Wire bassline and meticulous, precise drumming. The refrain is high-pitched and up-tempo, with machine-gun cymbals from Sean Moore.

songs.full_title: Roses in the Hospital by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Roses in the Hospital

description.plain: This song is about Manics' songwriter Richey Edwards' stint in a hospital, supposedly after the “4REAL” incident in which Edwards carved 4REAL into his arm with a razorblade when NME journalist Steve Lamacq questioned the band’s authenticity – the NME’s debate about this can be heard on the “Suicide is Painless” B-side, “Sleeping With the NME”. It shows the cynical, nihilistic yet also childlike scope of Richey’s mind at the time, though surprisingly most of the lyrics were actually written by Nicky Wire, presumably attempting to write from Richey’s perspective.

songs.full_title: Life Becoming a Landslide by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Life Becoming a Landslide

description.plain:
The fourth and final single from Gold Against the Soul “comes from the idea that the first thing a baby does is shriek at the horror of it all… as when you get to adolescence, the rewards of being older don’t really give you any satisfaction whether it’s getting a car or a fuck or a CD player”, as lyricist Richey James Edwards told Melody Maker music magazine in June 1993. The song begins quietly, with James’s voice accompanied only by an acoustic guitar, but the track opens out and becomes much noisier with the entrance of the drums, bass and electric guitars at the chorus.

“Life Becoming a Landslide” reached #36 in the UK charts, making it the least commercially successful single to come from the album.

songs.full_title: No Surface All Feeling by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: No Surface All Feeling

description.plain:
While often read as a goodbye to Richey Edwards, this song was actually demoed in January 1995, before Edwards disappearance. According to Simon Price’s book Everything, it is actually “inspired by Wire’s disenchantment with life in a rock group.” While the lyrics certainly seem to speak to Edwards absence, the timeline makes that impossible.

However, it’s still addressing the same underlying situation. Being in this band has changed their lives, and lead Wire to question whether or not the changes were worth it. This questioning leads to a self-examination of what it means to be heartfelt and sincere. There can be no greater love than one that is all feeling, no surface.

songs.full_title: Born a Girl by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Born a Girl

description.plain:
“Born a Girl” is the most pure and blissful track on This is My Truth Tell Me Yours, featuring only some delicately picked broken guitar chords and an accordion as an accompaniment for James Dean Bradfield’s vocals. The falsetto vocals and overall atmosphere of the song take inspiration from the late Jeff Buckley, who died only the year before.

The song’s chorus is fairly self-explanatory, addressing Nicky Wire’s wish that he had been born female, something that was reflected in his androgynous image in the early ‘90s. It is no surprise, then, that Bradfield, the only member of the band not to adopt this image in any way (besides Moore, who was frequently mistaken for a woman), reportedly felt rather uncomfortable singing the lyrics due to how personal they were to Wire.

songs.full_title: Sleepflower by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Sleepflower

description.plain:
The opening track of Gold Against the Soul is based on a heavy guitar riff that is doubled by the bass. Its lyrical content deals with the overuse of sleeping pills and other insomnia combatants in the modern age, as lyricist Richey James Edwards told Melody Maker in 1993:

Nobody seems to be able to get to sleep without artificial aid these days – whether it’s alcohol, pills, or even exercise programmes. Round where we come from, lots of people seem to walking around with muscles bulging everywhere, even if they’re only five foot two, and it’s unnatural to be like that. I don’t think it’s a matter of vanity, because it’s not as if anyone ever sees them.

songs.full_title: Motown Junk by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Motown Junk

description.plain:
This early Manics hit, released as a single before their first album came out, is one of the few songs from that era that remains a staple at the band’s concerts. They usually perform it after a partial cover of some pop song, such as Motown’s own The Supremes' “Baby Love” or 80s hits such as Van Halen’s “Jump” and The Cult’s “She Sells Sanctuary”.

Here it starts with “Baby Love” after a guitar riff quote of “Sweet Child O' Mine”:
https://youtu.be/_GZdWzfPzjs

Musically, “Motown Junk” is one of MSP’s most punk-oriented songs. And it also shows in the lyrics, particularly in the nihilistic attitude of the first verse. The lyrics also feature lines clearly aimed at causing controversy, in particular the one about the killing of John Lennon.

The words are basically a cry of youth rebellion against the establishment and in particular, against the status quo in pop music. The highly political songs sampled in the beginning and ending of the song – respectively by Public Enemy and The Skids – may be understood as the antithesis of the mindless music that’s attacked in the lyrics.

The single cover features a clock found in the ruins of Hiroshima showing the exact moment the atomic bomb detonated: 8:15 AM, August 6th, 1945. This may or may not have relation with the “168 seconds” mentioned in the chorus.

songs.full_title: Europa geht durch mich by Manic Street Preachers (Ft. Nina Hoss)
songs.title: Europa geht durch mich
songs.title_with_featured: Europa geht durch mich (Ft. Nina Hoss)

description.plain:
Inspired by the music of Simple Minds and travels through Europe and particularly Germany, “Europa Geht Durch Mich” is a rare celebration of Europeanism. Its stomping Krautrock is partnered by an expressly political lyric. Speaking to Mojo, James Dean Bradfield said:

“Europa Geht Durch Mich marches to its own logic, you have to go with it. Strap on the Teflon and bash the fuck out of it! I was confronted by the presence of the words, which made the music confrontational.”

Originally titled “European Miracle”, the song saw the Manic reunite with Alex Silva, who produced much of The Holy Bible. His partner, the actress Nina Hoss, sank the German lyrics. The opening line is lifted from “I Travel” by Simple Minds.

The song was the second single from Futurology, and was released with an official lyric video.

songs.full_title: My Little Empire by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: My Little Empire

description.plain:
“My Little Empire” is a dark and moody piece that bridges the gap between the first and second halves of This is My Truth Tell Me Yours. Nicky Wire takes pat-lead vocals for the first time in the Manics career, singing in a duet with James Dean Bradfield, and they are accompanied by only some light drumming, a John Frusciante-inspired guitar riff and a mournful ‘cello lead.

Bradfield told Q magazine that the song reflects “not caring or knowing about anything beyond your own four walls,” but it is also said to revolve around Wire’s anti-monarchist attitudes.

description.plain: “Ready For Drowning” is about the Welsh village of Capel Celyn, flooded in 1965 to create a reservoir, Llyn Celyn, in order to supply Liverpool and Wirral with water for industry. It is fairly mellow song that becomes more rocky in the choruses with the entry of James Dean Bradfield’s crunchy electric guitar.

songs.full_title: You’re Tender and You’re Tired by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: You’re Tender and You’re Tired

description.plain: “You’re Tender and You’re Tired” appears as the eighth track on This is My Truth Tell Me Yours and is a consolidation song for someone who has hit an emotional low. The track is driven forward by Nick Nasmyth’s piano playing in conjunction with James Dean Bradfield’s guitar chords and features whistling from Ken Barry, his only contribution to the record. The chord progression is unusual, shifting frequently between major and minor.

songs.full_title: The Love of Richard Nixon by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: The Love of Richard Nixon

description.plain: A song about former U.S. President Richard Nixon which sympathises with his achievements in office. Nixon resigned after the Watergate scandal in 1974. The song was released two weeks before the 2004 U.S. presidential election, in which George W. Bush was campaigning for a second term in office despite the fallout from the Iraq War.

songs.full_title: Repeat (UK) by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Repeat (UK)

description.plain: From the band’s first full-length album Generation Terrorists, “Repeat” is a protest chant against nationalism and the monarchy. Two edits appear on the album: this version and the “Stars and Stripes” version. Both versions have essentially the same lyrics but with different samples and instrumentation surrounding them, with the UK version being a more straightforward rock song.

songs.full_title: Prologue to History by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Prologue to History

description.plain: Originally released as a B-side to If You Tolerate This Your Children Will Be Next in August 1998 and later included on Lipstick Traces (A Secret History of Manic Street Preachers) in 2003, Prologue to History would be later included on the 20th anniversary remastered edition of “This Is My Truth, Tell Me Yours” replacing the track “Nobody Loved You”, a song written about the disappearance of lyricist/rhythm guitarist Richey Edwards to which the band apparently considered “outdated” in terms of their feelings on RIchey at that time.

songs.full_title: Patrick Bateman by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Patrick Bateman

description.plain: “Patrick Bateman” was featured as a B-side to “La Tristesse Durera”. Its title refers to the main character of Bret Easton Ellis’s American Psycho, and the lyrics explore the detached and violent themes of the novel. Rhythm guitarist Richey James Edwards has named the novel as one of his favourite books, so it is probable that most of the lyrical content came from him, as opposed to his co-lyricist, bassist Nicky Wire.

songs.full_title: Gold Against the Soul by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Gold Against the Soul

description.plain:
Manic Street Preachers' Gold Against the Soul closes with its apocalyptic title track. The lyrics were written by guitarist Richey James Edwards and bassist Nicky Wire, and Edwards told Melody Maker about the lyrics in a 1993 interview:

It’s an apocalyptic vision of Britain from the Thatcher years to the ‘caring Nineties’… The media thinks that if you’re working class, you’ve got to be one of two stereotypes – either tipping your cap to your employer, or a drug fiend permanently bombed out your skull. You’ve got to be a lager lout, or an effete Morrissey fan who never does anything. But working class people can be violent and sensitive.

Like “Nostalgic Pushead”, the rhythm section is mainly built on a percussion loop programmed by Sean Moore.

songs.full_title: Yourself by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Yourself

description.plain:
Another of the more rocky and aggressive tracks on Gold Against the Soul, “Yourself” rages at the human tendency to despise one’s own body image and never to be satisfied with the way you look, as Richey James Edwards told Melody Maker:

We humans are the only animals who are burdened with the knowledge that we’re going to die. So every day you look in the bathroom mirror and try to convince yourself that you look OK, so you can carry on with your daily routine, when actually you know that you’re a flabby piece of shit. It’s really difficult to keep feeling good about yourself when you keep seeing all these perfect, airbrushed images in magazines.

The verses are built on a slow, thundering bassline, later joined by a haunting, wailing guitar lead. In the choruses, however, everything speeds up, as Sean Moore’s drums transform from a mechanical plod into a quick shuffle.

description.plain: “I’m Not Working” is one of the most spacious and atmospheric tracks the Manics have ever produced, making innovative use of synths, yangqin (a kind of Chinese zither) and sitar to craft a sound unlike any other in the band’s catalogue. Its lyrics deal with themes of depression and the anticipation of death.

songs.full_title: Further Away by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Further Away

description.plain:
“Further Away” is the penultimate track off Manic Street Preachers' fourth album, Everything Must Go, as well as the third single in Japan, replacing “Kevin Carter”. However, unlike the other singles, it lacked a music video.

Although this song may be interpreted as a description of a complicated romantic relationship, given the recent events within the band, it almost certainly was written as a rumination on the surviving members' joys, sorrows and regrets at the loss of Richey James, who mysteriously disappeared in 1995.

songs.full_title: Send Away the Tigers by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Send Away the Tigers

description.plain:
This song, the title track for the Manics' eighth studio album, is about depression and the use of drugs to try and fend it off. Its title comes from a phrase by English comedian Tony Hancock, a favorite of Nicky Wire and Richey Edwards. As Wire stated:

He had a phrase ‘send away the tigers’ when his alcoholic demons and depression used to creep up on him.

songs.full_title: Drug Drug Druggy by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Drug Drug Druggy

description.plain:
“Drug Drug Druggy” is the sixth track on Manic Street Preachers' second studio album, Gold Against the Soul and features some of the most hardcore and powerful vocal delivery we’ve ever heard from James Dean Bradfield. Richey James Edwards, who co-wrote the lyrics with bassist Nicky Wire, described the words as:

 …just a very ambivalent attitude to drugs – and the different things that people use as drugs. Everybody has their own little obsession. I find it really annoying the way people come up to you and say ‘Hey, I just smoked a couple of joints and I’m really off my head.’ So what? If someone said ‘I’ve drunk 10 pints and I’m really out of it,’ you’d think they were pathetic, and it’s the same thing.

songs.full_title: Judge Yr'self by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Judge Yr’self

description.plain:
Judge Yr'self was originally recorded in 1995 but did not get a release until 2003 as part of the b-sides and rarities compilation “Lipstick Traces: A Secret History of Manic Street Preachers”.

The song was originally meant for the soundtrack to the 1995 film adaptation of Judge Dredd (to who Richey Edwards was a fan of the comic anthology 2000AD, referencing the series in the song PCP) however the song was likely shelved due to the disappearance of Richey that same year and the band’s hiatus until Everything Must Go.

The song is confirmed to have not been properly finished and is technically in a demo form.

Although the song was never released as a single, a promo video was made featuring clips from the bands years with Richey on tour, behind the scenes of photoshoots (particularly Traci Lords makes a small appearance) and from music videos, as well as some footage from the Everything Must Go recording sessions (particularly James Dean Bradfield using a punching bag shot by Nicky as recently seen in the Escape From History documentary) which received airplay on several music video channels and was included on the DVD included with the 10th anniversary edition of The Holy Bible in 2004 (although it was not included on the National Treasures compilation or DVD in 2011).

The song was also performed live only a handful of times in 2003, mostly during in-store shows promoting the release of Lipstick Traces.

songs.full_title: Nostalgic Pushead by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Nostalgic Pushead

description.plain:
“Nostalgic Pushead” is the upbeat-sounding eighth track on Manic Street Preachers' Gold Against the Soul, one of two tracks in which the drums and percussion are actually samples programmed by drummer Sean Moore. Richey James Edwards, who co-wrote the song alongside bassist Nicky Wire, told Melody Maker about the song’s meaning in 1993:

It originally started off with the idea of a middle-aged person knocking things that would be exciting and valuable to a new generation. So many people said to us when we started. ‘Oh, seen that, done it, don’t do it again.’ It’s really depressing that there’s a new generation growing up and being offered the same icons, like The Rolling Stones. The biggest bands now, like Pearl Jam, obviously grew up listening to the same records their parents did. But the whole Sixties perspective of change no longer exists.

songs.full_title: Futurology by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Futurology

description.plain:
The title track from Futurology was written entirely by Walk Me To The Bridge. Musically, it is inspired by both David Bowie’s Berlin trilogy (sounding most reminiscent of Lodger) and Krautrock. James Dean Bradfield sings lead vocals, but Nicky’s vocals are also comprehensible during the chorus.

With its lyrics that deal with return and optimism and its stomping beat, it is a natural opener. It’s also more stadium friendly than a typical Manics track.

Cian Ciaran of Super Furry Animals plays keys, and, in Nicky’s words, lays down “some sonic textures”. James thought he was perfect:

In my head, I was trying to think of who was one of the most distinctive keyboard players of the last two generations and Cian was at the front of the queue.
A lot of his stuff is beautiful. He’s got a rock ‘n’ roll sensibility coupled with a real experimental sensibility as well and that’s exactly what we needed.
“Futurology” has got that Krautrock driving beat and so has “Next Jet To Leave Moscow”. He just seemed like the perfect answer. As I say he mixes the rock ‘n’ roll and the experimental in such a brilliant way.

songs.full_title: Symphony of Tourette by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Symphony of Tourette

description.plain:
“Symphony of Tourette”, as its title suggests, is about Tourette’s Syndrome, a disease that affects your speech and can, in many cases, cause you to inadvertently and uncontrollably swear or make vulgar gestures. Co-writer and rhythm guitarist Richey James Edwards went further into the meaning of the song in an interview with Melody Maker in 1993:

It’s almost as if [people with Tourette’s are] saying what everyone else secretly wants to say. Because most people spend their lives doing things they don’t really want to do, and no one gets to tell that irritating little man to fuck off.

Suitably, therefore, the track is perhaps the most aggressive on Gold Against the Soul, being built on one of the Manics' heaviest guitar riffs and featuring more profane language than any other track on the album.

songs.full_title: Black Square by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Black Square

description.plain:
If in context with the Russo-European themes of  the rest of “Futurology”, then it’s likely that “Black Square” means the suprematist painting by Russian artist Kazimir Malevich. Malevich was a pioneer in abstract art, and frequently his paintings were made up of simple geometric shapes.



His paintings went against those approved by the Stalinist regime, and he was banned from exhibiting and creating similar art. In this song the Manics have used Malevich’s art as a symbol of how communist oppresion affected every area of people’s lives and stripped away basic human rights.

songs.title: Socialist Serenade

description.plain: Socialist Serenade is a response to the U-Turn of Tony Blair and New Labour in 1997 to which they initially promised that Tuition Fees for university students would be kept free as they had been since 1976 when they were originally abolished. However only months into his term in Downing Street, Blair (following inquiries into education funding) made a U-turn on his promise and introduced tuition fees in late 1997.

songs.full_title: Underdogs by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Underdogs

description.plain:
Released as a free digital download in March 2007, Underdogs is technically the first single from Send Away The Tigers and was their comeback single following their short-Hiatus following the release of Lifeblood.

A fan contest was launched online so fans can collaborate and be part of a short music video of the track interspersed with archive clips of the band
https://youtu.be/2GYCRTvRSHc

Although a free download, the track was met with a mixed reception from some fans due to several issues they found with the track in terms of the lyrical content, the apparent “Loud” and “Aggressive” nature of the track and very notably a poor edit in the song which can be heard following the first chorus. The band, most particularly drummer Sean Moore, is seen to comment on the poor reception to the song in the documentary “No Manifesto” which primarily follows the Manics during the making of Send Away The Tigers.

The track was later scrubbed from the 10th anniversary release in favour of B-Side “Welcome To The Dead Zone” although a demo version of Underdogs is present.

songs.lyrics:
Put some lipstick on
At least your lies will be pretty
A shadow on my face
And us donkeys wake up weary
Sweating and sickly
Donkeys don't allow their tears
No emotion never feel
And drown themselves in whatever

Find some meaning
Donkeys weight cracking a spine

Sweetness bent double
Whole days making polite
Never moving out of turn
Or even trying to be natural
Those with silence inside
Eyes bare piss holes in the snow
Drained and burnt yellow
And sunk in self-pity

Jerusalem sawn off
Donkeys are only left with lies
Are only left with liesEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

annotatable.title: Blank Diary Entry

songs.lyrics:
In a garden full of locusts
Pain was a crying man
Wrapped in several kinds of skin
Seeking consolation in machines

Stuck in a hole of collapsing time
Locked into solitude by body state and mind
A silent tension drags and weakens
In a hollow room the darkness deepens
The curve steepens

Just another blank diary entry
The emptiness tells its own story
Blank diary entry
A slow painful goodbye to glory - goodbye to glory

A gentle murmuration concealed to all but me
Estranged sad and softened
In a low sky by the sea – patiently

Disciplined desirеs and toxic agendas
Polished by light yet still half rеmembered
Fatigued - tired ragged and distressed
No way out of this unholy mess - I must confess

Blank diary entry - the emptiness tells its own story
Blank diary entry - a slow painful goodbye to glory
Goodbye to gloryEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Baby Elian by Manic Street Preachers
songs.title: Baby Elian

description.plain:
Named about the Elian Gonzalez Affair in which a young boy, Elian, became embroiled in controversy between Cuba and the USA regarding immigration.  The song uses this affair to comment on USA-Cuban relations.

The Manics played this song when they famously became the first Western artists to play in Cuba for over 20 years, with Cuban leader Fidel Castro rising to applaud the song.
